Key Match Events: Tyler O'Neill ended the game with a three-run homer off Keegan Akin in the 10th inning and sending the ball over the Green Monster and onto Lansdowne Street.
Emmanuel Rivera hit a go-ahead RBI single in the top of the 10th to cap a 2-for-4 performance that also featured a third-inning home run.
Pre-Game Insights: The Orioles expressed optimism that Tuesday was a turning point, but they lost the series despite a well-rounded game.
Post-Match Reflections: Akin said, “Definitely frustrating, you know? We’re at kind of a crucial point right now. Haven’t really been playing our best ball, but I think it’s coming, I do. You’re starting to see a little bit of it. Just got to kind of put it all together at one time, and I think we’ll go from there.”

Rivera said via team interpreter Brandon Quinones, “We have to keep going out there with the same mentality, stay strong and not trying to change too much. We have to go out there and be strong, and get the job done.”
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Orioles (83-64) sit 1 1/2 games behind the first-place Yankees (84-62) in the American League East standings.
The Orioles haven’t been playing like a team capable of going on a deep postseason run, with a 25-26 record since the All-Star break and five of their past seven losses.
The Orioles have 15 games remaining and still sit atop the AL Wild Card standings, with a three-game advantage over Kansas City (80-67), the current second Wild Card.
Others: The Orioles manager Brandon Hyde could have intentionally walked the right-handed-hitting O’Neill to load the bases, but the Sox likely would have then sent Rob Refsnyder to the plate in place of Masataka Yoshida.
